data: The inscription runs on the underside of the foot.
end of the 6th-beginning of the 5th century BCE (Sudano 2015).
Discovered in 1916 by P.Orsi among the grave goods in one tomb in the necropolis of Casa Cantoniera.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.
Greeks and Sikels in the Hyblaean Area: an Historical Interpretation of the Epigraphic Evidence in the Chalcidian Hinterland

Nella Sudano, ‘Greeks and Sikels in the Hyblaean Area: An Historical Interpretation of the Epigraphic Evidence in the Chalcidian Hinterland’, in SOMA 2011: Proceedings of the 15th Symposium on Mediterranean Archaeology, Held at the University of Catania 3-5 March, vol. 2, 2 vols (Oxford, 2015), 699–708

Luciano Agostiniani e Federica Cordano, «L’ambiente  siculo», in Il Guerriero di Castiglione di Ragusa. Greci e Siculi nella Sicilia sud-orientale (Atti del Seminario di Milano, 15 Maggio 2000), Hesperìa 16 (Roma: L’Erma’ di Bretschneider, 2002), 77–89
I nomi dei vasi greci nelle iscrizioni dei vasi stessi
M.L. Lazzarini, ‘I Nomi Dei Vasi Greci Nelle Iscrizioni Dei Vasi Stessi’, Archeologia Classica 25–26 (1974 1973): 341–75
Grammichele. Fittili con un verso del comico Frinico
Paolo Orsi, ‘Grammichele. Fittili Con Un Verso Del Comico Frinico’, Notizie Degli Scavi Di Antichità, 1920, 336–37
Domenico Comparetti, «Varietà epigrafiche siceliote», Archivio Storico per la Sicilia Orientale 16–17 (1920 1919): 194–203
Terravecchia di Grammichele. Storia di un insediamento della Sicilia orientale tra indigeni e Greci
Marco Camera, Terravecchia di Grammichele. Storia di un insediamento della Sicilia orientale tra indigeni e Greci, Edizioni Quasar, Antico (Roma, 2020)
ολτεσϙο ΖΕΥΔΑΙΕΔΑΞΕΔΑ ποτερο

1ολτεσϙο ΖΕΥΔΑΙΕΔΑΞΕΔΑ ποτερο

1oltesco ZEUDAIEDAXEDA potero

1ΟΛΤΕΣϘΟΖΕΥΔΑΙΕΔΑΞΕΔΑΠΟΤΕΡΟ

1OLTESCOZEUDAIEDAXEDAPOTERO

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Sudano 2015

English translation

Italian translation

commentary

The inscription was initially interpreted as Greek by Comparetti (consulted by Orsi himself) who read a verse from the comedy Ephialtes by Phrynicus (Comparetti 1919-1920, 200-203), followed in the Greek interpretation by Manganaro (1968, 202). Subsequent editors soon recognised its non-Greek nature: thus Lazzarini (1973-1974, 344-346), who attributed it to the Etruscan area; Agostiniani and Cordano (2002, 82-83) who, supporting a more likely thesis - partly as a result of comparisons with other indigenous sites in eastern Sicily - suggested that it is an inscription in an indigenous language (i.e. Sikel) that nevertheless presents several linguistic loans from Greek. In particular the word 'poteron' = gr. ποτήριον, from which it could be inferred that the inscription, also considering the type of vessel, is a ludic one which refers to the symposial context.

The inscription was initially interpreted as Greek by Comparetti (consulted by Orsi himself) who read a verse from the comedy Ephialtes by Phrynicus (Comparetti 1919-1920, 200-203), followed in the Greek interpretation by Manganaro (1968, 202).
